title-group.article-title: Enhanced laser-driven proton acceleration using nanowire targets

institution-wrap.institution: National Agency for New Technologies, Energy and Sustainable Economic Development

abstract.title: Abstract

institution-wrap.institution: Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada
Fonds de recherche du Québec – Nature et technologies

custom-meta.meta-value: Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, multidisciplinary
Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, multidisciplinary

sec.title: Introduction
NW geometry optimization
Experimental campaign
Underlying physical phenomena and discussion
sec.p: In conclusion, this work is the first to present a systematic study of the enhancement provided by nanowire targets for laser-driven proton acceleration in terms of the relevant geometrical parameters d, g and l, but also regarding their influence on the proton spectra characteristics (proton maximum energy, temperature and total number) in the TNSA regime, hence providing a comprehensive understanding of the proton beam enhancement with nanostructured targets. Experimental evidence exhibits high enhancement ratios for the proton spectra characteristics, in agreement with PIC simulations. A geometry optimization was also performed through PIC simulations allowing to define the best parameters for the LLC laser characteristics. A larger gap value of g = 800 nm between the nanowires is expected to provide even higher enhancement ratios according to our simulations. The aforementioned improvements will be the subject of a subsequent study. The easy production method along with the high enhancement ratios provided by NW targets open very promising avenues for laser-driven proton beam generation on ultra-high power laser facilities, where the proton energies would be of strong interest for material science, medical applications and laboratory astrophysics.

sec.title: Nanowire Production
PIC simulations

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: This work is supported by FRQNT (nouveaux chercheurs, Grant No. 174726, Equipe 2016-PR-189974), the National Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) (Discovery Grant RGPIN-2018-05772 and the Alexander-Graham-Bell Graduate Scholarship for S.V.), Compute Canada (Job: pve-323-ac) as well as the Canada Foundation for Innovation (CFI). This study has also received financial support from the French National Research Agency (ANR) in the frame of “the Investments for the future” Programme IdEx Bordeaux-ANR-10-IDEX-03-02, from the Swedish Research Council (VR) and the Knut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation (KAW). Concerning the use of the Lund Laser Center, we acknowledge support by Laserlab Europe (Grant Agreement 654148 under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme). We would like to thank Tsuneyuki Ozaki for the fruitful discussions, Anders Persson, Riccardo De Angelis and Pierluigi Andreoli for the technical support and Claudio Verona for lending us some equipment.

sec.title: Author contributions
sec.p: S.V., M.S., A.P., K.S., G.C., F.C., C.G.W. and P.A. conceived and conducted the experiments, S.V., M.S. and G.C. analyzed the experimental results, S.V. developed and analyzed the simulations under the guidance of E.H., Z.C. and S.S. developed and produced the nanowires, Z.C. and S.V. performed SEM on the nanowires, C.G.W., E.H. and P.A. supervised the project, S.V. and P.A. wrote the manuscript. All authors reviewed the manuscript.

sec.title: Competing interests
sec.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
